entry.title: Combined summary - Auto-generated miner backbone
entry.summary: In various email exchanges and discussions related to Bitcoin mining, several proposals were suggested to address the issue of sybil nodes and selfish mining attacks. One proposed solution involved embedding IP addresses of nodes into coinbases to automatically build a miner backbone, while another suggested defining a standard in the coinbase to commit to extra data appended to the block message. However, some argued that these proposals could lead to centralization of infrastructure or create new vulnerabilities. Additionally, the profitability of selfish mining strategies and the impact of factors such as latency and pool centralization were discussed. Overall, more thought and analysis is required before any changes are implemented to the current system.In various email exchanges and discussions, several proposals were made to address the miner backbone issue in the Bitcoin protocol. One suggestion involves embedding IP addresses into coinbases to build a miner backbone, but it was later realized that this approach could make attacks easier to carry out. Another proposal suggests propagating all competing branches of equal length and choosing which one to mine on uniformly at random, but a member disagrees with the proposal, stating that it does not address the sybil attack issue that is at the core of the problem. Peter Todd suggested using "near-blocks" to estimate the hashing power on each fork and switch to the majority side if necessary, which effectively defeats the selfish-miner strategy and puts the 51% attack threshold back at 51%. Furthermore, the correct approach for miners is to always mine to extend the block that the majority of hashing power is trying to extend, but there is no stable way to know what the majority is. To address this issue, relaying all blocks that meet the PoW target and relaying block headers that nearly meet the PoW target were proposed. Lastly, a feedback effect was suggested, where once one half finds a near-target PoW solution, the corresponding block-header would be broadcast on the network, and miners can switch to extend the majority block. Overall, various solutions were proposed, but careful thought and analysis are required before implementing any changes to the current system.The emails and discussions referenced cover a range of topics related to Bitcoin, including the issue of selfish mining, proposals for changing the protocol, and concerns about centralization. While some proposed solutions, such as delayed blocks and authenticated miner announced nodes, were refuted due to potential weaknesses or incentives for larger pools, others, like randomizing the order of broadcasts or using near-target headers, were seen as promising in defeating selfish-miner strategies and establishing consensus among miners. Additionally, there was debate over whether fundamental rule changes should be made, with one proposal being particularly contentious because it would allow anyone to broadcast a newly discovered block at any time and have a 50% chance of winning, thus altering the dynamics of how Bitcoin works. Overall, the conversations highlighted the importance of considering potential risks and challenges before implementing any significant changes to the current system.In a series of email conversations between various Bitcoin experts, the topic of mining strategies and potential attacks on the network was discussed. One such attack is the selfish mining attack where an attacker can keep newly mined blocks secret and broadcast them only after another miner finds a block, in order to orphan the other miner's chain and increase their own revenue. However, it was argued that this strategy may not be profitable in practice due to the need for well-connectedness in all miners and the ability to randomize the order of broadcasts. The use of deterministic pseudo-random mechanisms for choosing between competing chains can alleviate concerns about rational motivations of individual miners. The possibility of de-incentivizing selfish mining by randomizing the order of broadcasts and the idea that practicing instead of theorizing may be more useful are also mentioned. In addition, various factors such as latency, nLockTime, and the centralization of pools and mining hardware are discussed in relation to the profitability of selfish mining strategies. The conversation also touches upon the vulnerability of Bitcoin mining pools to attacks by selfish miners, and suggests implementing rules to prevent such attacks. Another topic of discussion is the concept of near-target PoW solutions, which can give miners honest proof of what the majority actually is and thus defeat selfish mining attacks. However, it is noted that even with near-target headers, very quickly all hashing power will come to consensus and all work to extend the same block, either theirs or the attacker's. Overall, the email conversations highlight the various vulnerabilities and potential attacks on the Bitcoin network, as well as proposed solutions to address them.
